image.altText: a young man with auburn hair and glasses smiling at a desk

items.synopsis: Lawyers servicing an area twice the size of Tasmania reveal their biggest challenges as calls continue for urgent funding for Aboriginal legal services.

title.children: Clients without a phone or home address – these are just some of the barriers lawyers in Katherine face daily

image.altText: An illustration shows a mosaic of personal data, with a search field for email addresses.

items.synopsis: Have you ever wondered how much of your personal information is available online? Here's your chance to find out.

title.children: Find out what data is available about you online — but be warned, it might feel a little creepy

image.altText: A man with a medium-length beard wearing a black beanie, headphones around his neck and a grey hoodie

items.synopsis: With New Zealand police now treating the fatal fire at a Wellington hostel as arson, former residents recall how they managed to escape the burning building and the stark conditions inside.

title.children: When his NZ hostel caught fire, Simon had to convince his neighbours the building was really burning

image.altText: Don Matheson with a football team logo behind him

items.synopsis: The former owner of the Northern Queensland Fury football club, Don Matheson, is now at the centre of a joint investigation between Papua New Guinea police, Interpol, and Australian authorities.

title.children: International taskforce launches investigation into whether Australian entrepreneur paid bribes to officials

image.altText: An illustration of a woman undergoing a mammogram.

items.synopsis: Breast density isn't related to breast size, nor can it be determined by touch or feel — and there's debate over whether women should know about it.

title.children: 'Women need to know about risks': Why concerns about breast density are dividing doctors and patients

image.altText: Prince harry in an open-collard shirt and grey jacket, holds hands with his wife Meghan in a beige halter neck

items.synopsis: The couple's office says the pair and Meghan's mother were followed for more than two hours by half a dozen vehicles after leaving a charity event in New York on Tuesday.

title.children: Prince Harry and Meghan in 'near catastrophic car chase' while being followed by paparazzi

image.altText: A man wears a lanyard with the Australian Government coat of arms on it.

items.synopsis: Labor has set itself a modest target for winding back government spending on external contractors, but it may prove much tougher to meet than expected.

title.children: Public servants may get a real pay rise, but it's unlikely to lure contractors back

image.altText: A paparazzi photographs Prince Harry at nighttime

items.synopsis: After a lifetime of camera flashes and intimate front-page spreads, this is the story of how Prince Harry became an enemy of the tabloid media.

title.children: Why Prince Harry's paparazzi feud is personal

image.altText: A middle-aged man in a suit with glasses speaks behind a microphone-laden lectern in front of the Sydney Opera House.

items.synopsis: Anthony Albanese's biggest challenge, a year after being sworn in as PM, has been dealing with global uncertainty — this week in the form of the US being gripped by the "blocking and disruption" of its polarised domestic politics, writes David Speers.

title.children: Joe Biden bailing on Australia is a reminder of Albanese's biggest challenge as PM

image.altText: two men close up

items.synopsis: Independent MP Alex Greenwich had previously threatened to sue Mark Latham for defamation if the One Nation MP did not apologise or attempt to make amends.

title.children: Independent MP to sue One Nation's Mark Latham for defamation over offensive tweet

image.altText: Sylvia Massara in her home, pictured with her cat

items.synopsis: A charity-run housing estate will raise rental prices by 10 per cent – which residents like Sylvia Massara will struggle to afford.

title.children: Australia's rental market tightens further as rental price increases reach 30 per cent in some areas

image.altText: A school bus rolled onto its side with the impact of a crash visible, with emergency services walking behind.

items.synopsis: As Melbourne's outer-suburban sprawl has inched towards Exford Primary, the school has retained its country feel — and it was a sense of community that kicked in after Tuesday's horror bus crash.

title.children: Exford Primary School bus crash leaves Eynesbury community and first responders reeling

image.altText: Jazeer Nijamudeen wears a suit jacket and stands looking seriously in front of a fence and soil.

items.synopsis: At the Allura estate in Melbourne, like in many new housing developments, residents say they've waited years for infrastructure. The Consumer Action Law Centre is now calling on the state government to toughen laws for developers.

title.children: Residents bought into this estate on the promise of a bustling town centre. A decade later, it's still empty land

image.altText: Two men sitting in front of a kitchen. The man on the left wears a plaid shirt and the man on the right a green t-shirt.

items.synopsis: Two tradesmen who ran to help at the site of Tuesday's school bus crash in Melbourne tell of the horrific scenes they faced as they tried to rescue the children.

title.children: Children in bus crash found yelling 'where's mum?' when rescuers arrived

image.altText: Woman in a pink fur coat wearing gold glasses with dollar signs on the front of the frames.

items.synopsis: If assisted reproductive technology is going to help our future fertility problems, should the government be helping women cover the costs of this pricey procedure? Some doctors say yes, others say it's a "can of worms".

title.children: Costs remain a barrier to egg freezing, so should the government subsidise it?

image.altText: A woman with short hair and glasses stands  in front of a house

items.synopsis: Tenants caught up in the housing crisis are being advised to stay in their rentals after being served with notices to vacate so they can buy more time to search for new accommodation.

title.children: Joanne stayed on after her landlord asked her to vacate. It bought her time

image.altText: A man holding his foot up to the camera.

items.synopsis: When Peter Bedford, 74, decided to seek treatment for a fungal toenail, he had no idea it would lead to major heart surgery.

title.children: How a check-up on Peter's feet led to life-saving heart surgery

image.altText: Three little girls give a peace sign while a man takes a photo

items.synopsis: Known as the forbidden kingdom, Bhutan is famous for its national pursuit of happiness and for being carbon negative. But it is also caught between two feuding giants.

title.children: Sandwiched between two feuding superpowers, Bhutan, the happiest nation on Earth has a choice to make

image.altText: Olena Fedosieieva, in bright red shirt, stands with hands in pockets in front of lush, green trees smiling.

items.synopsis: Despite growing up with Russian as her dominant language, Olena Fedosieieva has now largely ditched the language in a show of solidarity. And she's far from alone.

title.children: 'When you speak Russian, you have a great pain.' At 48, Olena decided to switch languages and she's not alone

image.altText: Aerial image of a series of lush green islands in a blue ocean. Clouds meet the horizon.

items.synopsis: The United States and Palau agree to renew a key strategic pact as part of US efforts to shore up support among Pacific island states, to counter competition from China, despite President Joe Biden postponing plans to visit the region.

title.children: United States agrees to renew strategic pact with Palau amid Chinese competition in the Pacific

image.altText: Woman with hair in bun and blue cardigan wearing glasses sitting down

items.synopsis: A group of senior legal academics from New South Wales and Victoria write to the NSW attorney-general, urging him to use his power to immediately release Kathleen Folbigg from prison.

title.children: Senior academics call for early release of Kathleen Folbigg

image.altText: A man and a woman dancing outside

items.synopsis: Excitement is building in Sydney — especially in the suburb of Harris Park, otherwise known as 'little India' — as thousands of Indian Australians prepare for the first visit by the Indian leader in almost 10 years.

title.children: Indian Australians prepare for Narendra Modi visit despite cancellation of Quad leaders summit

image.altText: A partly completed building behind a fence

items.synopsis: Contractors fear they will see as little as five cents in the dollar after a building company collapses in Hobart, leaving contracts for half-built homes torn up.

title.children: Homes half built, contractors owed thousands after building company collapse

image.altText: Dirty earth

items.synopsis: Global temperatures are set to break records in the next five years, with a 98 per cent chance one will be the warmest ever recorded, according to a new report from the UN's meteorological agency.

title.children: There's a 98 per cent chance one of the next five years will be the hottest ever, new UN report says

image.altText: A missile blasting off leaves a fireball in its wake

items.synopsis: Scientists in Russia have expressed their concern about their ability to continue doing their jobs if they risk being accused of treason.

title.children: Russia says hypersonic missile scientists face 'very serious' treason accusations

image.altText: A composite image of small metal and plastic bands removed from magpies, and a magpie fitted with the tags holding its leg up.

items.synopsis: Victoria's Conservation Regulator is investigating reports of birds tagged with what are thought to be illegal bands in Melbourne's west. In the meantime, a concerned resident has stepped in to rescue them.

title.children: 'Distressed' magpies fitted with 'homemade' tags prompt animal cruelty investigation

image.altText: A muscly black man in black shirt and pants and a white woman in black crop and bleached jeans stand in front of large vehicles.

items.synopsis: Jason Momoa enters the franchise as the vengeful son of drug kingpin Hernan Reyes on a mission to terrorise Vin Diesel’s Dom Toretto and tear down his racing empire.

title.children: Fast and Furious or Bold and the Beautiful? Latest movie in franchise veers from fun to ridiculous

image.altText: Aerial view of a suburb covered in flood water.

items.synopsis: There have been days of heavy rain across a broad swath of northern Italy and the Balkans, with "apocalyptic" floods, landslides and evacuations reported in Croatia and Bosnia.

title.children: Multiple deaths as 'apocalyptic' floods sweep through northern Italy, Croatia and Bosnia

image.altText: A formula one car on a race track with a checkerboard flag visible.

items.synopsis: Formula One said it made the decision for safety reasons and to avoid any extra burden on the emergency services, after consulting with Italian political figures.

title.children: Emilia Romagna F1 Grand Prix called off due to extreme weather in northern Italy

image.altText: A police 4x4 is parked in front of a crime scene and firefighters and police examine the area

items.synopsis: New Zealand police say they are treating a hostel fire in which at least six people died as arson as they open a homicide investigation.

title.children: New Zealand police say arson suspected in deadly Loafers Lodge hostel fire

image.altText: A man stands in the front of soldiers

items.synopsis: China slapped one of the country's best-known comedy companies with a $3.1 million penalty, accusing it of "harming society" after a military joke made by one of its comedians drew strong public criticism.

title.children: Xi Jinping slogan used in joke by comedian results in $3 million fine for comedy troupe

image.altText: An Apple logo hangs above the entrance to the Apple store in Manhattan, New York City

items.synopsis: The US Justice Department outlines five cases against people it has charged as part of efforts to stop its technology from falling into the hands of what it calls its "foreign adversaries".

title.children: US charges former Apple employee accused of stealing technology before fleeing to China

image.altText: Close up of blonde haired woman in dressed in black.

items.synopsis: Disgraced Theranos chief executive Elizabeth Holmes will start serving her prison sentence while she attempts to overturn the conviction.

title.children: Elizabeth Holmes loses latest bid to avoid prison, ordered to pay $678 million in restitution

image.altText: Comedian Hannah Gadsby, with short hair, glasses and a dark blue shirt, holds a microphone on-stage.

items.synopsis: In their new Netflix stand-up show ‘Something Special’, Hannah Gadsby is done with the doom and gloom – at least for now.

title.children: Hannah Gadsby's new TV special celebrates love and happiness – but there's no slowing down yet

image.altText: Magpies coach Nicole Richardson gives her team some direction in a huddle

items.synopsis: Collingwood are one of the biggest powerhouses in football, so why aren't they using that money to prop up their struggling Super Netball team, are the state associations holding the sport back and who is likely to be the league's eighth team next season if the Magpies fold?

title.children: Why is the richest AFL club struggling to fund its Super Netball team?
